It would be a major usability improvement if the blog-posts macro could be configured to additionally show the space in which a blog post was published. We use compounded news feeds for groups of spaces, and cannot currently use the blog-posts macro for that since the user cannot see which space the news applies to. A simple *showSpace* parameter could take care of this.

Adding a *showDateModified* parameter would help the user see that a blog post has been updated since it was posted. This can of course be seen in RSS feeds for instance, but this way it would even be evident from browsing the blog posts list. Of course some might prefer to have the modified date _in stead of_ the created date. So why not add a *showDateCreated* parameter as well?

Finally, adding a *showLabels* parameter to allow labels _not_ to show in news feeds would make the news layout cleaner. We sometimes use lots of labels but they are only useful in classifying news, not for displaying in the news feed.

Cheers!

By default, Tomcat has a (configurable) 2MB limit on the size of post data. This limit can be reached when submitting a large page, which leads to Tomcat logging an error, and the form data being truncated. The web application has no knowledge of this, so the user cannot be notified.

If instead of a urlencoded form, we used a multipart form, the container will not enforce a limit and leave that up to the application. Depending on servlet version, the parsing may also be the application responsibility.

We should:
* Change the form to be a multipart form
* Only parse the form data if the user has permissions to edit the page
* Enforce an admin configurable limit on the post data size for that page.
* Display an error message to the user when the limit is exceeded (currently it just continues blissfully ignorant of the fact that it doesn't have all the data)

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

h4. {+}The root cause that NPE occurs.{+}
In letter case conversion of the attached file name including the full-width alphabet character, the performed results of both Java "java.lang.String#toLowerCase()" method and PostgreSQL "lower()" function are *NOT* same.

h5. 1. If the input is half-width upper alphabet character (A~Z)
|| || Java\\java.lang.String#toLowerCase() || PostgreSQL lower()\\LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8 || PostgreSQL lower()\\LANG=C ||
|| output | half-width lower alphabet char (/) | half-width lower alphabet char (/) | half-width lower alphabet char (/) ||

h5. 2. If the input is full-width upper alphabet character (Ａ~Ｚ)
|| || Java\\java.lang.String#toLowerCase() || PostgreSQL lower()\\LANG=ja_JP.UTF-8 || PostgreSQL lower()\\LANG=C ||
|| output | full-width lower alphabet char (/) | full-width lower alphabet char (/) | full-width upper alphabet char (x) ||
\\
We guess that this looks like PostgreSQL-specific problem fundamentally.
In PostgreSQL, initializing database with "C" locale setting (--no-locale) is strongly recommended. Please refer the following description for more detail:
{quote}
The drawback of using locales other than C or POSIX in PostgreSQL is its performance impact. It slows character handling and prevents ordinary indexes from being used by LIKE. For this reason use locales only if you actually need them.
http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.4/interactive/locale.html
{quote}

h4. {+}The solutions for this problem (Proposal).{+}

# *(Recommended)* It is the most desirable to fix the Confluence application.\\So we really want to know the method.
# Initializes database with "japanese" locale and unifies the locale settings of both Java VM and PostgreSQL.\\But as previously described, it cannot recommend to use PostgreSQL with the locale setting except "C" basically.
# Fixes the source code of the lower function of PostgreSQL.\\However, even if this problem has been resolved by the fix, the possibility to widen impact to the outskirts (e.g. other applications connecting to PostgreSQL) is extremely high. So we would like to absolutely avoid the only way to fix PostgreSQL source code directly.

h4. {+}The impact on Japanese customers and marketing.{+}

Most Japanese customers routinely use both full-width alphabet and digit characters to the filename.
It is the very fatal function restrictions for Japanese customers, unless they can use full-width alphabet character to the name of the attached file, and it influences Confluence sales activities in Japan greatly.

h4. {+}A step-by-step of how to reproduce this.{+}
# Download the file (ABC.txt, filename alphabets except an extension are all full-width characters) that I attached here.
# Log in Confluence that you installed on the testing environment.
# Attach the downloaded ABC.txt file in Confluence page.

(i) We installed the above environment *with English language default settings*.
fields.summary: NPE - when attaching a file that the filename contains full-width alphabet character using PostgreSQL

From Charles Hall:
{quote}
We've recently upgraded from Confluence 2.8 to 3.2. The left navigation theme was a popular choice for many wiki spaces, but now most users seem to be transitioning well to the new documentation theme.

We did have one comment though from a user expressing some disappointment that the space search built into the left sidebar of the documentation theme was not a "live" search. Through the use of the "Navigation" page, many users had added both live search and pagetree, so I can sympathise that they felt there was a small loss of functionality with the new documentation theme.

However, we took a look at the velocity template for the documentation theme (doctheme-page.vmd) and have made a small mod so that live search is now offered in place of the regular search. Here's the mod:

Before (lines 6 to 10):

{noformat}
            #if (!$params.get("mode").contains("edit"))
            <content tag="tree">
            $helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{pagetree:root=@home|searchBox=true}")
            </content>
            #end

            After:

            #if (!$params.get("mode").contains("edit"))
            <content tag="tree">
            ## CHCH 26/08/10 - Replaced Pagetree search with Live Search
            $helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{livesearch:spaceKey=$spaceKey}")
            $helper.renderConfluenceMacro("{pagetree:root=@home|searchBox=false}")
            </content>
            #end
{noformat}
{quote}

Based on discussion over at the manual:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Viewing+an+Older+Version+of+a+Page?focusedCommentId=223221050#comment-223221050

I've come here to file the bug as suggested.  Specifically, for archival/audit purposes, we want to be able to link to older versions of a page.  This is currently possible, but only at the cost of using an opaque identifier.  This means, to verify that a link points to the right page, you actually have to follow the link, and see the name of the page.

I have two uses for this:
On the current version of a page, I want to link to an older version of the same page - for example to indicate the version of a page that was "approved".

On some other page, I want to be able to gather up links to a collection of pages related to some particular subject, and capture the state of those documents at a particular point in time.

Both of these can be done now, but at the cost of click-through to verify the correct link.  This makes tracking links to older versions of pages far more error prone.  For example, I might easily link to the wrong version of a page, or I might put add a typo, an invalid opaque ID, and not link to anything at all, thus losing the original intent.

There seems to be some inconsistencies in the edit/view page-level restriction permissions.

I searched the previously submitted bug reports and a lot of them have been resolved as "Not a bug". I at least disagree. Take the following example:

We have 2 administrators, admin1 restricts the page with the the view restriction to himself. This means that admin1 is added to the list of people who are able to view the page, all other users can not see the page except admin2 user (as he is an administrator, but he also cant see the page in the spaces page tree for example). 

Now, lets say the admin1 is on holiday and the restricted page needs editing. The admin2 user can not edit the page until he removes the restriction that admin has placed for himself. This is quite simple to do, but a small amount of unnecessary work. 

But what if there were restrictions for 10 people? What if the groups and users are retrieved through LDAP and no logical group can be used, and 10 single restrictions were required? The admin2 user would first have to remove the 10 people from the restrictions, edit the page, then add the 10 people again (since no logical LDAP group can be used) This is totally unnecessary overhaul for the administrators. Administrators should be able to edit the page even though it is restricted to whoever. Of course we could create a LDAP group with those 10 users, but this too is an overhaul that some companies can not afford, and even with this resolution, the admin2 user would first have to remove the restriction, edit the page, then add it again. 

I understand from the previous submissions that this is how it is supposed to work, that the user does not accidentally see (i.e. in the spaces pagetree view) or accidentally edit a page (a restricted edit page) that he/she isnt supposed to edit, but the administrator should be on top of this and know the details. 

To help the administrator notice the restriction, as a solution I suggest a new feature, that all restricted pages (view or edit) have a noticeable panel to the administrators that this is a restricted page, either view or edit, without removing the edit function from the page, because this creates unnecessary overhaul, one way or another.

Would like a site-wide option for restricting notifications to email only a link the the changed pages, not the contents of the page itself.


In our setup, our Confluence setup is secure (only available via HTTPS) but various email systems that our users use are not. Many of them use public email addresses.  


When Conflucene emails a notification of a change. It emails the entire content of the Confluence page. In effect copying what was a secure page and placing it onto the public domain.


There used to be a third party plug-in that provided this functionality but that doesn't work in version 3.3.


Sch an elementary feature should be part of Confluence especially given how email has become so insecure.


In the ole-days everyone used a company supplied server which they used to access their email that could presumably be made secure but today not all small companies operate like this anymore and allow people use their gmail.com, yahoo.com, etc. email addresses instead.


In this situation, having Confluence send only a link to the content is critical, IMHO

  {panel}

When starting selenium tests, the first thing that's supposed to happen is that the framework tries to install a test helper plugin in confluence. Under Windows 7 with the default Tomcat settings, this plugin cannot be uploaded, which prevents all tests from running. It fails inside the native WinNTFileSystem code while trying to create a temp file under <TOMCAT HOME>/temp, probably due to Windows 7 Windows-on-Windows permissions differences (Tomcat is installed under Program Files, which is protected and files created/modified without elevated privileges are instead written to the c:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Local\VirtualStore of the active user).

java.io.IOException: Access is denied
        at java.io.WinNTFileSystem.createFileExclusively(Native Method)
        at java.io.File.checkAndCreate(File.java:1345)
        at java.io.File.createTempFile(File.java:1434)

The exception itself is a known JDK bug (see http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6325169) and has been open 5 years now, as it has occurred on various versions of Windows. We should seriously think about detecting this sort of failure and reporting it to the user, or even changing the default install settings of tomcat so it never tries to use a tempdir under Program Files.

A workaround is to pass the JVM arg -Djava.io.tmpdir=c:\tmp (or some other unprotected dir) to tomcat.

If a user macro "jira" is defined as "Macro generates wiki markup" using the following definition:

\[$param0|http://jira.yourcompany.com/browse/$param0\]

We expected uses of the user macro to expand and cause trackback linking to take effect.

The use case for this is project planning pages or build report pages that list many JIRA issues. It is a lot easier to specify \{jira:JIRAKEY-1\} than to specify \[JIRAKEY-1|http://jira.yourcompany.com/browse/JIRAKEY-1\], and the former has the additional benefit of being portable allowing us to change the link definition if our instance of JIRA were to move (it is - we were just purchased by another company).

We've looked at AppLinks, but this has been problematic for us and we understand it won't be out until later. Also, I don't know if AppLinks supports two-way linking as trackback linking does?

We're looking at user macros as being a simple expansion, and in this case, we're expecting trackback linking to take effect on the simple expansion.
